title: State pension set to rise by 4pc
text:
Retirees in receipt of the state pension are in line for a 4pc boost in payouts next year thanks to the Government’s gold-plated protections.

Since 2010, the “triple lock” means that the amount received by state pensioners, currently £168.60 a week, rises each year by either 2.5pc, the rate of inflation or wage growth – whichever is highest. The inflation figures used are for the year to September, due to be announced in the next few weeks.

Pensions firm Aegon said the current rate of wage growth means payouts can be expected to increase by 4pc from April next year. This would bring payments for someone with a full national insurance record to £175.35 a week.

Since 2010, the amount received from the state by a single person has grown by almost a third. The expected rise would be the highest since 2012, when inflation was 5.2pc.

Steve Cameron, from Aegon, said: “This will be welcome news for current state pensioners. However, these inflation busting increases do come at a significant cost.
